Post Text: Is it a job or a mission?People with a purpose are easy to spot - their energy is infectious.Their work isn't a job, it's a mission.They believe in it, they're passionate about it, they go the extra mile.Working just for the pay check is no way to live.Becoming great at something and wanting to make a difference with your skills is how we find purpose and meaning to life.So, how can you use your skillset and turn your work into a mission? ‚û°Ô∏è Passionate Pursuit: Find what truly ignites your passion and aligns with your values. Discover the area where your skills and interests converge, and where you feel most alive. ‚û°Ô∏è Lifelong Learning: Embrace a growth mindset and commit to continuous learning. Stay curious, seek out new challenges, and strive to expand your knowledge and skills. ‚û°Ô∏è Seek Mastery: Strive for excellence in everything you do. Post Text: Nobody is thinking about you.I meet a lot of business owners who worry about what people think.They don't act on an idea because...."My competitors might copy me""Someone might not like it""People may disagree with my point"Most of the time, these are PROJECTIONS of fear.A hypothetical negative outcome to justify not taking action.It's all made up.That's FEAR.Fear invents hypotheticals to stop us taking action.Fear tells you your competitors could steal your idea, so don't talk about it.It's also true that potential clients might see your idea and want to buy it.Fear doesn't want us to consider the upshot.It wants us focused on the downside.Fear is a muscle that, once exercised, becomes harder and harder to defeat.

Post Text: I've set goals and failed to achieve them.I've written down goals and never hit them (here is why).- I didn't integrate my goals into my daily activities.- I didn't make my goals smart ( it was a wish list).If you write goals more like a wish list, here is what happens...- Unimportant tasks will take priority.- You won't have daily actions to move you closer to your goals.- Your action taking will be inconsistent / make it up as you go along.But there is something worse...You'll lose confidence in achieving your goals. It will create doubt. You'll have a sneaking suspicion your goals are impossible.It becomes a vicious circle.You don't take the goals seriously, so you fail to hit them. You doubt the goal is possible, so you don't want to put effort into them.It's vicious circle that confirms you can't achieve your goals.BUT if you do want to hit your goals, you need to make them smart.You need SMART goals - goals that are clear and actionable. SPECIFIC - MEASURABLE - ACTIONABLE - RELEVANT - TIME-BASEDWrite down your SMART goals.Then diarise the actions you need to take.Example:Specific: Get more leads per week from social media.Measurable: 4 Leads per week.Actionable: Posting 3 times per week, grow my network, offering a lead magnet to new connections.Relevant: More connections will increase my reach, leads will help me win clients.Time-bound: By 7th May 2024, I'll be getting 4 leads per week. SMART goals are the way to achieve things.Set your goals, make them SMART and work on them every day.

Post Text: I had a very weird encounter with a bunch of rich people in London.It changed my view on money ‚¨áÔ∏èI went to pitch my services to a prospect, it turned into a long lunch with some City execs.It started at 12pm and ended at 8pm and I was ¬£20k better off.During the 'meeting' I was telling my prospect how I could help but the conversation would drift all over the place.It was difficult as it turned from a meeting into social.I felt like I was wasting my time.I finally got my proposal out and told him it was ¬£5k for 3 months.I'd never met any of these people before and I had no idea why 4 other people showed up.I was ready to call it quits and write the day off, then something even weirder happened....Then this fiery discussion got started about why they should all sign up.I was pitching one person. Post Text: Can you make SERIOUS money social selling?Yes - here is how ‚¨áÔ∏èI saw a YouTube video the other day from some 20-something claiming you can get thousands of leads."Post content on LinkedIn and you'll get thousands of leads like I did"That is tripe.The attract model only works if‚Ä¶.you pursue high impressions, followers and reach.Waiting for the leads to come to you means you need huge engagement, a big following and serious investment in content.If you don't become one of the top 1% of users, that's impossible.You need to be working your LinkedIn 20+ hours per week.That's madness and impossible for most solopreneurs.If you want to make ¬£200k from LinkedIn this year, here is what you need to do ‚¨áÔ∏è‚û°Ô∏è Focus on one decision maker (Ideal clients)‚û°Ô∏è Sell ONE service to solve ONE of their problems‚û°Ô∏è Your profile should be all about them and your ONE service‚û°Ô∏è Post about the solution and problem consistently‚û°Ô∏è Grow your network with your Ideal Clients‚û°Ô∏è Build relationships and start conversations in the DMs‚û°Ô∏è Host audio events and webinars to educate them‚û°Ô∏è Follow up and book offline conversationsDo that over and over.People buy from people.You don't need a big crowd to make it work.

Post Text: "Content impressions don't matter"- That's only 60% true.Likes, comments and impressions are vanity metrics right?Well, that's easy to say when you get huge reach.But back in the real world, when you get 100 impressions and 3 likes, that platitude feels like a kick in the nuts.The truth is the world is a bit shallow:‚û°Ô∏è We do connect popularity with credibility.‚û°Ô∏è We do get a positive feeling from engagement.‚û°Ô∏è We do build more awareness with higher reach.High engagement does make you money.But 90% my impressions came from people who aren't my ideal client.Did it feel good, yup.Did it help me get more widely known, yup.Did it make me money, yup.Impressions and engagement build your brand and shape perceptions.Should you pursue that? Well, there might be simpler and easier option....There are two games in town....‚û°Ô∏è The Reach Game - Build a big audience, get high engagement, attract leads.‚Üí Broader content.‚Üí More personal stories.‚Üí More entertainment.‚û°Ô∏è The Resonance Game - Build deep relationships, educate your ideal client through content and start conversations‚Üí Building relationships.‚Üí More insightful content.‚Üí More relevance.I'm playing both games.Over the last 3 months I've been working harder on relationships. I've also been testing different tactics with content and gaining reach.Guess which one gets the most money in the bank?RELATIONSHIPS.It's 3:1 lead so far in 2024.‚û°Ô∏è 33 new clients from relationships.‚û°Ô∏è 12 new clients from content.We all want lots of leads and engagement, it's a lie to think otherwise.But If I was a solopreneur, I'd be 100% focusing on the relationship game.It's faster, more profitable and easier.The big money is in the relationships you build on LinkedIn.

Post Text: How I went from charging ¬£200 a day to ¬£2k+ dayAs a solopreneur back in 2007, I'd get a ton of price objections.I'd drop my price or discount to win business.It took me living just-above-broke and being embarrassed about not being able to buy Christmas presents for my kids to force me to change. I was damned if I was doing this again.So in 2008, I worked a bit harder, marketed more. I was running around like a headless chicken selling myself for ¬£200 a day.Just to pay my bills, I needed 10 clients a month.That's a lot as a solopreneur.‚û°Ô∏è I got some tough love from a friend."Dean, you are the problem here. You are trying to sell high value with a bargain basement approach"That cut, but he was right.I'm struggling to get ¬£200 a day, when some are getting thousands per day.I knew my skill and expertise was up to it.How I marketed and packaged what I did was the problem.I could make excuses to make myself feel better, but it wouldn't change anything.It was a ME problem. I changed everything my offer, target audience, message and process.I would hourly have to fight myself to not revert back to the old way.I was unsettled because the phrenetic-ness was gone.‚û°Ô∏è Not being overworked felt WRONG.I was so used to chasing things down and working like a dog, this new world felt uncomfortable.The old Dean would be loaded up with client work and throwing everything at getting more work just to survive.New Dean wasn't doing any of that.After a few wobbles, I signed my first client at ¬£750.Then the following month got my first client paying ¬£2k.Within two months, I had 10x my prices and made the same money doing a fraction of the work.PS - 15 years later, I still have some of those clients with me.

Post Text: "I can't get social selling to work for me"‚û°Ô∏è This is how I made it work.I've been on social media since the beginning back in the early 2000s.Back then I was a solopreneur marketing consultant, so I dabbled in everything.I found social selling really hard.I was torn between what to sell, how to sell it and who to sell it to.The confusion and indecision in my head translated into my pitiful results.I was like a rabbit in headlights.So, I reached a point, where I told myself, I need either nail this or quit.But, I was also aware of what the alternatives where:Expensive paid adsEmail outreachNetworkingOf course, even changing to another way of marketing, I had the same problem....What to sell, How to sell it and Who to sell it to.The problem wasn't a social media issue, it was a focus issue in my head.So, I decided we needed to focus sell one thing:Marketing Timebank - a fixed number of hours from our team helping you with websites, copywriting and design for busy B2B owner run businesses that don't have budget for a full-time marketing person.I went to social media with Marketing Timebank.#1 - Only sell one thing to one person.#2 - Grow my connections with those people#3 - Post content which gets people to know me better (SEE)#4 - Post helpful content for my audience (TASTE)#5 - Make a weekly offer on a post and in the DMs to new contacts (BUY)That was it.That's all I did.Over and over again.More than 55 people signed up to the Time Bank and hired 12 people in the first year.Lessons for me: FOCUS + REPEATABLE PROCESSNow, it's changed a bit since then, but we still work on the same planYour defined audience need to SEE, TASTE and BUY.If you want a more detailed version of my 5 Point Plan - comment below or DM me.

Post Text: How prospects use social media is different from us.This changed totally changed my approach ‚¨áÔ∏èSocial media is like NetflixMost login with no agenda, just looking to pass the time.They scroll looking for something, but not specific.Something catches our eye and we dip into it.On Netflix we choose what to watch based on: üé¨ Other peoples recommendations / reviewsüé¨ What genre you're interested inüé¨ What you've watched beforeüé¨ What the cover looks likeüé¨ What mood you're inüé¨ What we see firstOn social media, prospects are scrolling to pass the time.They aren't in the headspace of buy right there and then.They're discovering stuff and responding as it comes at them.This means right now, prospects are on a journey of discovering you.‚úÖ Here is the point - If you watched an actor's film before and enjoyed it, you'll give a film more consideration.If it's totally unknown, if it hasn't flipped our switch in the first few minutes we switch off.I started a series the other night. Less than 5-minutes in, I checked out. It just wasn't for me. Then I got into Fool Me Once by Harlan Coben, loved it and checked out all the other Harlan Coben series.This how people respond to us online.The principle is simple - we extend more grace to things we've had a positive encounter with before.Most don't get that.They overthink it or forget we are marketing to humans, not analytical robots.They think prospects should read their messages and reply.They believe promoting their offer should logically lead to sales.More positive encounters your prospects have with you, the more consideration they'll give you.They'll be more open to giving you their time and attention.Yes - we have to make an offer to them.Yes - we have to promote what we do.But how and when we do it matters.
